skill.name: container-grype
skill.description: Container vulnerability scanning and dependency risk assessment using Grype with CVSS severity ratings, EPSS exploit probability, and CISA KEV indicators. Use when: (1) Scanning container images and filesystems for known vulnerabilities, (2) Integrating vulnerability scanning into CI/CD pipelines with severity thresholds, (3) Analyzing SBOMs (Syft, SPDX, CycloneDX) for security risks, (4) Prioritizing remediation based on threat metrics (CVSS, EPSS, KEV), (5) Generating vulnerability reports in multiple formats (JSON, SARIF, CycloneDX) for security toolchain integration.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill with no executable code. Contains only markdown documentation and YAML configuration templates for the open-source Grype vulnerability scanner. No scripts, network calls, or file system access beyond its own documentation files.

content.value_statement: Container images often contain known security vulnerabilities in operating system packages and application dependencies. This skill provides guided workflows for scanning images with Grype, interpreting CVSS scores, prioritizing based on CISA KEV indicators, and integrating security gates into CI/CD pipelines.
actual_capabilities: Scan container images for CVEs using Grype
Interpret CVSS severity scores and EPSS exploit probability
Configure CI/CD pipeline security gates with fail thresholds
Prioritize remediation using threat intelligence indicators
Generate vulnerability reports in JSON, SARIF, and CycloneDX formats
limitations: Requires external installation of Grype and Docker tools
Does not perform actual scanning itself - provides documentation and workflows
No automatic remediation - only guidance on fixing vulnerabilities
Relies on external vulnerability databases (NVD, CISA) for CVE data

use_cases.title: CI/CD Security Gates
use_cases.description: Integrate container scanning into build pipelines with severity-based fail thresholds to block vulnerable images from production.

use_cases.title: Vulnerability Triage
use_cases.description: Prioritize remediation efforts using CVSS scores, EPSS probabilities, and CISA KEV indicators to focus on actively exploited vulnerabilities.

use_cases.title: Pre-Deployment Scans
use_cases.description: Scan local container images before pushing to registries to catch and fix vulnerabilities early in the development cycle.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Scan
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I scan a Docker image with Grype to find vulnerabilities? Show me the basic command and how to interpret the output.

prompt_templates.title: CI/CD Integration
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me configure a GitHub Actions workflow that runs Grype vulnerability scans and fails the build if critical vulnerabilities are found.

prompt_templates.title: Prioritization
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain how to prioritize container vulnerabilities using CVSS scores, EPSS exploit probability, and CISA KEV indicators. Show me the risk hierarchy.

prompt_templates.title: Report Generation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a SARIF report from Grype scan results that integrates with GitHub Security tab. Include JSON output options for SIEM ingestion.

output_examples.input: Scan myapp:latest Docker image for vulnerabilities and help me prioritize the fixes
output: ‚Ä¢ 3 High (CVSS 7.0-8.9) - CVEs in base image packages
RECOMMENDED ACTION: Focus on Critical vulnerabilities first. CVE-2024-1234 is in CISA KEV (actively exploited). Update alpine:3.14 base image to 3.19 or apply security patches.

best_practices: Set fail-on thresholds appropriate for each environment - critical for production, high for staging, medium for development.
Use SBOM-based scanning with Syft for faster re-scans during development without re-analyzing full image layers.
Document all suppressed vulnerabilities with justification and expiration dates to maintain audit trail.
Integrate SARIF output with GitHub Security or security dashboards for centralized vulnerability tracking.
anti_patterns: Ignoring low-severity vulnerabilities without assessment - some may indicate deeper security issues.
Using overly broad ignore rules that suppress legitimate vulnerabilities across all packages.
Scanning only new images - re-scan production images weekly to catch newly disclosed CVEs.
Setting fail-on thresholds too high (critical only) in CI/CD, allowing high-severity vulnerabilities to reach production.

faq.question: What container platforms does Grype support?
faq.answer: Grype scans images from Docker, podman, OCI registries (ECR, GCR, Docker Hub), and local tar files. It analyzes Alpine, Ubuntu, Red Hat, Debian, and other distributions.

faq.question: How often should I update the vulnerability database?
faq.answer: Run grype db update before each scan or at least daily. New CVEs are published continuously, so daily updates ensure you catch recent disclosures.

faq.question: Can I use Grype without Docker installed?
faq.answer: Yes, Grype can scan directories, SBOM files (Syft, SPDX, CycloneDX), and tar archives without Docker. Docker is only required for live container image scanning.

faq.question: How is my scan data handled?
faq.answer: Grype downloads vulnerability metadata from public databases (NVD, GitHub Advisory Database). No scan results are sent anywhere unless you explicitly configure output or upload SARIF to GitHub Security.

faq.question: Why does Grype report vulnerabilities in packages I do not use?
faq.answer: Grype scans all packages in the image including transitive dependencies. Use --only-fixed to show only vulnerabilities with available patches or create .grype.yaml ignore rules for false positives.

faq.question: How does Grype compare to Trivy or Snyk?
faq.answer: Grype is open-source, lightweight, and integrates well with CI/CD. Trivy offers more integrated registry scanning and Aqua provides commercial features. All three use similar vulnerability databases.
